subject: Ethics
title: History of Business Regulation
description: A quick, practical guide to History of Business Regulation.

hook.text: In 1906, a novel about meatpacking was so disgusting that the president read it and changed the law.

buildup.text: Upton Sinclair's 'The Jungle' exposed rotting meat sold to consumers. The FDA was born from public outrage.

discovery.text: Business regulation follows a pattern: scandal, public fury, new law. Repeat every few decades.

twist.text: After each wave of regulation, industries lobby to weaken the rules. Deregulation caused the 2008 financial crash.

climax.text: Regulation is a pendulumâ€”too little breeds exploitation, too much stifles growth. The balance is never permanent.

punchline.text: Every major regulation has a horror story behind it.

quiz.question: What pattern does business regulation historically follow?
options: Gradual, steady improvement without any triggering events
Corporate scandal, public outrage, then new regulation
Businesses voluntarily regulate themselves before any problems occur
